Description: Glucosidase activity, if occurring in mitochondria, would be involved in the breakdown or modification of carbohydrates, fitting into the broader carbohydrate metabolism pathway.

G-protein complexes are central to signal transduction. While primarily associated with plasma membrane receptors, some G-proteins or related signaling components can have roles in mitochondrial signaling or regulation, placing it under the general 'Signaling' category.

Pathway: Metabolism > Vitamin metabolism > Folate and 1-C metabolism
Description: Dihydrofolate reductase is a key enzyme in folate metabolism, reducing dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, which is essential for one-carbon metabolism, a pathway explicitly listed under vitamin metabolism.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting
Description: The INA complex (Inner membrane protein assembly complex) is directly involved in the assembly and insertion of proteins into the mitochondrial inner membrane, a core aspect of mitochondrial protein import and sorting.

While a cellular location, mitochondria are actively trafficked and localized within specific cytoplasmic regions, including the perinuclear area. This localization and movement falls under the broader category of mitochondrial trafficking and dynamics.
Homoserine is an amino acid intermediate in the biosynthesis of other amino acids (methionine, threonine, isoleucine), directly fitting into the amino acid metabolism pathway.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Iron homeostasis
Description: This GO term directly describes the process of iron import into the mitochondrion, which is a critical aspect of mitochondrial iron homeostasis, essential for Fe-S cluster and heme synthesis.

Magnesium is an essential metal cofactor for numerous mitochondrial enzymes and processes. Its binding activity is fundamental to the function of many proteins within the broader category of metals and cofactors metabolism.

Multivesicular bodies are endosomal compartments involved in cellular sorting and degradation. While not a direct mitochondrial pathway, their assembly is part of broader cellular organelle management and trafficking systems that can indirectly influence mitochondrial quality control and dynamics.

GO_description: stress-induced homeostatically regulated protein degradation pathway

Description: This pathway describes protein degradation for maintaining homeostasis, especially under stress. Mitochondria possess their own proteases and protein quality control systems, which are integral to protein homeostasis and degradation within the organelle.
Acetate transport across mitochondrial membranes is a specific instance of small molecule transport, which is a dedicated category in the hierarchy.

This is a general cellular trafficking process. While not directly mitochondrial, it represents a broader cellular system of organelle and cargo movement, which can indirectly relate to the cellular context of mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance and organelle interactions.
Mitochondria play a crucial role in buffering intracellular calcium and are central to calcium signaling. This GO term directly aligns with the 'Calcium homeostasis' pathway under 'Signaling'.

GO_description: positive regulation of exit from mitosis
Description: This term describes a cell cycle regulatory process. While mitochondrial function is linked to cell cycle progression, the regulation itself is mediated by complex cellular signaling pathways, placing it under the general 'Signaling' category.

Pathway: Metabolism > Amino acid metabolism > Lysine metabolism
Description: Homoaconitate hydratase is an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of lysine, directly fitting into the specific 'Lysine metabolism' pathway.

Pathway: Metabolism > Vitamin metabolism > Folate and 1-C metabolism
Description: This enzyme is involved in the polyglutamylation of tetrahydrofolate, a critical step in folate metabolism, which is part of the 'Folate and 1-C metabolism' pathway.

GO_description: hydrolase activity, acting on ester bonds
Description: This is a broad enzymatic activity. Many mitochondrial enzymes are hydrolases involved in various metabolic processes, such as lipid metabolism or protein processing. 'Metabolism' serves as the most appropriate general category.

GO_description: G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle
Description: This term describes a critical phase transition in the cell cycle. While mitochondria provide energy and signaling cues for cell division, the G1/S transition itself is governed by complex cellular signaling networks, placing it under the general 'Signaling' category.

Mitochondria have highly organized membrane structures, particularly the inner membrane forming cristae. 'Cristae formation' is a specific and crucial aspect of mitochondrial membrane organization, directly fitting this category.
Malonate is a small molecule that can be transported across mitochondrial membranes. This activity directly falls under the 'Small molecule transport' pathway.

While primarily an ER/Golgi process, mannose is a carbohydrate, and this enzyme complex processes mannosyl-oligosaccharides, linking it broadly to carbohydrate metabolism, which can have mitochondrial connections or implications.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > Polycistronic mtRNA processing
Description: This term explicitly refers to the processing of mitochondrial tRNA, which involves cleavage from polycistronic transcripts, a key step in mtRNA metabolism.

Description: The 90S preribosome is an intermediate in ribosome assembly. Assuming a conceptual parallel for mitochondrial ribosome biogenesis, this term relates to the formation of mitochondrial ribosomes.
Porins, such as VDAC in the outer mitochondrial membrane, are channel proteins that facilitate the transport of small molecules across membranes.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Proteases
Description: Metallodipeptidases are a class of proteases, enzymes involved in protein degradation and processing, which are crucial for mitochondrial protein homeostasis.

Mitochondrial dynamics (fusion, fission) and morphology are known to influence overall cellular morphology and growth patterns, including filamentous growth, making this the most relevant category for a cellular phenotype influenced by mitochondrial state.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: This term directly describes a specific modification of mitochondrial tRNA, which is a core process within mtRNA metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA repair
Description: DNA recombination is a process of genetic exchange often involved in DNA repair mechanisms, which are essential for maintaining mitochondrial DNA integrity.

GO_description: extrinsic component of mitochondrial inner membrane
Description: This term describes a protein component localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane. Its presence and correct localization are governed by protein import and sorting mechanisms, and its stability by protein homeostasis.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > Polycistronic mtRNA processing
Description: This is a specific type of tRNA processing, analogous to 3'-end processing, often occurring during the maturation of mitochondrial tRNAs from polycistronic transcripts.
Cardiolipin is a unique mitochondrial phospholipid. Proteins that bind cardiolipin interact with this key lipid, placing this function within the broader context of lipid metabolism.

Description: Hydroxypyruvate reductase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of glyoxylate, which is closely linked to serine and glycine metabolism within the broader amino acid metabolism.
Transaminases catalyze the transfer of amino groups, a fundamental reaction in the synthesis and degradation of amino acids, many of which occur in mitochondria.
Phosphatidylinositol phosphates are a class of phospholipids. Proteins binding these lipids are involved in phospholipid-related processes, fitting into phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: Mitochondria are central to cellular redox homeostasis, being major producers of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and housing key antioxidant systems like the glutathione system.

Similar to N-linked glycosylation, O-linked glycosylation involving mannose is a protein modification. While primarily extra-mitochondrial, the involvement of mannose links it broadly to carbohydrate metabolism.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting
Description: Although this term specifies peroxisomal import, the general process described is 'protein import'. This category represents the overarching mechanism for protein delivery to organelles, including mitochondria, and is the most general fit for the process type.

GO_description: re-entry into mitotic cell cycle after pheromone arrest
Description: Mitochondria play a role in regulating cell cycle progression and cellular responses to stress or external cues through various signaling pathways, making 'Signaling' the most appropriate general category.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting
Description: Translocon complexes (e.g., TOM, TIM) are fundamental to the import and sorting of proteins into and within mitochondria, making this the direct parent category for such complexes.

GO_description: double-strand break repair via break-induced replication

Description: Double-strand break repair is a critical mechanism for maintaining the integrity of DNA. Mitochondria possess their own DNA and repair systems, including mechanisms for double-strand breaks.

Myosin II is a motor protein involved in cytoskeletal interactions. Mitochondrial movement and positioning (trafficking) within the cell often involve interactions with the cytoskeleton.
This is a specific form of autophagy. While targeting the nucleus, it falls under the general cellular process of autophagy, which is a key mitochondrial surveillance mechanism (mitophagy).

GO_description: regulation of dolichyl monophosphate biosynthetic process
Description: Dolichyl monophosphate is a lipid involved in glycosylation. Although not directly mitochondrial, dolichol is a lipid, placing its biosynthesis under general lipid metabolism.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Carnitine synthesis and transport
Description: Carnitine is crucial for fatty acid transport into mitochondria. This GO term encompasses the broader metabolism of carnitine, including its synthesis and transport.

GO_description: obsolete peptide mating pheromone maturation involved in positive regulation of conjugation with cellular fusion
Description: This GO term describes a process involving pheromones, which are signaling molecules. While not directly mitochondrial signaling, it fits the general 'Signaling' category as the most appropriate top-level pathway.
Mitochondria are central to cellular responses to toxic substances, often involving detoxification pathways and ROS metabolism.

GO_description: mitochondria-associated endoplasmic reticulum membrane contact site
Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Organelle contact sites
Description: This term directly describes a specific type of inter-organelle contact site, which is explicitly listed in the hierarchy.

This term broadly covers the various steps involved in processing mitochondrial proteins, including import, folding, and proteolytic cleavage, which are all aspects of protein homeostasis.

GO_description: DNA-(apurinic or apyrimidinic site) endonuclease activity
Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA repair
Description: This enzyme activity is crucial for DNA repair. Mitochondria contain their own DNA (mtDNA) and possess specific repair mechanisms.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Tetrahydrobiopterin synthesis
Description: Dihydroneopterin aldolase is an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of tetrahydrobiopterin, a critical cofactor.

GO_description: invasive growth in response to glucose limitation
Description: This describes a complex cellular response to nutrient stress. Metabolic adaptation is fundamental to surviving glucose limitation, making 'Metabolism' the most appropriate general category.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Iron homeostasis
Description: Mitochondria play a central role in cellular iron homeostasis, as iron is essential for many mitochondrial proteins (e.g., Fe-S clusters, heme).

Mitophagy is the selective degradation of mitochondria by autophagy, a process explicitly listed in the hierarchy.

Description: L-leucine is a branched-chain amino acid. Its biosynthesis is a specific process within amino acid metabolism, directly fitting the 'Branched-chain amino acid metabolism' category.

Pathway: Metabolism > Amino acid metabolism > Glutamate metabolism
Description: L-glutamate catabolism is a specific process within amino acid metabolism, directly fitting the 'Glutamate metabolism' sub-pathway.
This enzyme activity is involved in electron transfer, making it an electron carrier within the broader metabolic context.

Description: The catabolism of mRNA directly relates to the stability and decay of mitochondrial RNA.
Translational termination is an integral part of the mitochondrial protein synthesis process.
Dioxygenase activity is a general enzymatic function involved in various metabolic reactions, making 'Metabolism' the most appropriate broad category.

Description: This GO term directly refers to the regulation of L-proline metabolism, which is a specific sub-pathway under amino acid metabolism.
The succinate-CoA ligase complex is a direct component of the TCA cycle, a central pathway in carbohydrate metabolism.
While the peroxisomal matrix is a cellular component, its functional relevance to mitochondria often involves inter-organelle communication and contact, which falls under 'Organelle contact sites'.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > NAD biosynthesis and metabolism
Description: NADH kinase activity is directly involved in the interconversion and metabolism of NAD/NADH and NADP/NADPH, which are crucial cofactors.
Binding to double-stranded DNA in mitochondria is fundamental for processes like mtDNA replication, repair, and nucleoid organization, all falling under mtDNA maintenance.

GTPase activator activity is a regulatory function that modulates GTPase activity, a common mechanism in various cellular signaling pathways.

Description: The mitochondrial processing peptidase complex is directly responsible for cleaving presequences from proteins imported into the mitochondria, a critical step in protein import and sorting.

GO_description: ATPase-coupled monoatomic cation transmembrane transporter activity
Description: This activity describes an ATPase-driven transporter for monoatomic cations across membranes, which is a fundamental aspect of small molecule transport in mitochondria.

Description: The catabolism of hydrogen peroxide is a key process in detoxifying reactive oxygen species, directly fitting into the 'ROS and glutathione metabolism' pathway.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA replication
Description: The replisome is the protein complex responsible for DNA replication, and in mitochondria, this directly corresponds to mtDNA replication.

Description: This GO term directly describes the process of forming mitochondrial cristae, which is explicitly listed as a pathway under 'Cristae formation'.
This GO term describes the regulation of apoptosis, a process where mitochondria play a central role, and which is explicitly listed as a pathway.

GO_description: cytoplasmic side of endoplasmic reticulum membrane
Description: While this GO term describes an ER location, the interaction between the ER and mitochondria occurs at 'Organelle contact sites,' which are crucial for mitochondrial function and dynamics.

Description: NADP is a crucial coenzyme involved in various metabolic reactions, closely related to NAD, and its binding is part of the broader 'NAD biosynthesis and metabolism' pathway.

Description: Metalloaminopeptidase activity is a type of proteolytic activity, essential for protein processing and degradation within mitochondria, falling under the 'Proteases' category for protein homeostasis.

Description: This enzyme activity is directly involved in the metabolism of NAD(P)H, which are essential cofactors, fitting precisely into NAD biosynthesis and metabolism.

This is a fundamental cellular process of cell division. While not a mitochondrial pathway itself, it is a highly regulated event. 'No appropriate pathway' is the most general category for regulated cellular processes in the hierarchy.

Myosin II is a cytoskeletal component involved in general cellular processes like cell division and motility. While not a mitochondrial complex, its activity is highly regulated. 'Signaling' is the most general category for regulated cellular processes in the hierarchy.

Maltose catabolism is a carbohydrate metabolic process. While not directly mitochondrial, it contributes to the overall cellular carbohydrate pool that can feed into mitochondrial pathways.
Mitochondria have their own translation machinery, and the regulation of its fidelity is an integral part of the overall translation process within the organelle.

Description: Mitochondria possess their own set of aminoacyl-tRNA ligases (mt-tRNA synthetases) essential for charging tRNAs for mitochondrial protein synthesis.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA replication
Description: Mitochondria contain their own DNA (mtDNA) and replicate it. Binding to replication origins is a fundamental step in mtDNA replication.

Description: This process refers to the modification of tRNA molecules, which in the context of mitochondria, are essential for mitochondrial translation and are specifically modified within the organelle.

Description: This GO term describes a specific catabolic pathway for the amino acid L-lysine, which is a core component of mitochondrial amino acid metabolism.

GO_description: tricarboxylate secondary active transmembrane transporter activity

Description: The disassembly of protein complexes is a critical aspect of protein quality control and turnover, ensuring proper protein homeostasis within mitochondria by removing damaged or unneeded complexes.

Description: This is a specific type of methylation occurring on tRNA molecules, which in mitochondria, contributes to the essential modifications of mt-tRNAs required for proper mitochondrial translation.

Chromatin refers to the complex of nuclear DNA and proteins. While mitochondria contain their own DNA, it is organized into nucleoids, not chromatin. However, 'mtDNA nucleoid' represents the mitochondrial equivalent of a DNA-protein complex.
Lipoate is an essential cofactor for several mitochondrial enzyme complexes. Its biosynthesis and subsequent insertion onto target proteins are critical mitochondrial metabolic processes.

Kinetochores are structures involved in chromosome segregation during cell division. Description: This term describes a specific type of signal transduction regulation. While the specifics (pheromones, conjugation) are not typically mammalian mitochondrial, the overarching process is 'Signaling,' which is a top-level mitochondrial pathway.

Description: Phosphate is a fundamental component of nucleotides (e.g., ATP, ADP), and its metabolism is intrinsically linked to mitochondrial energy production and nucleotide synthesis/processing.

Description: NADP+ is a critical redox cofactor, metabolically related to NAD+, and its metabolism is essential for various mitochondrial processes, including antioxidant defense and biosynthesis.

Description: Mitochondria possess their own ribosomes, and the maturation of their large subunit ribosomal RNA (LSU-rRNA) is a crucial step in mitochondrial ribosome assembly and function.

Description: G-quadruplex structures can form in mitochondrial DNA and their binding proteins are involved in regulating mtDNA stability, replication, and transcription.

COPI coating is involved in vesicle-mediated transport within the secretory pathway. While not directly mitochondrial, this category broadly encompasses cellular trafficking and organelle interactions, making it the least inappropriate fit for a non-mitochondrial transport term within the given hierarchy.

Description: Mitochondria are critical hubs for cellular iron metabolism, including iron-sulfur cluster biosynthesis and heme synthesis, making them central to intracellular iron ion homeostasis.

GO_description: establishment of protein localization to endoplasmic reticulum membrane

Description: The mitochondrial nucleoid is the protein-DNA complex containing the mitochondrial genome, essential for mtDNA maintenance within the organelle.

Mitochondria are central to cellular calcium ion homeostasis, actively participating in calcium uptake, release, and buffering, which is directly covered by this pathway.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > Transcription
Description: This GO term describes the fundamental process of synthesizing RNA from a DNA template, which occurs in mitochondria using mtDNA as a template.
While a cell cycle event, the G1 to G0 transition is influenced by cellular energy status and signaling pathways, in which mitochondria play a significant role.

GO_description: negative regulation of homoserine biosynthetic process
Description: Homoserine is an amino acid, and the regulation of its biosynthesis falls directly under the broader category of amino acid metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: This process involves attaching threonine to its specific mitochondrial tRNA, a function performed by mitochondrial threonyl-tRNA synthetases, which are essential for mitochondrial protein translation.

GO_description: amino acid catabolic process to alcohol via Ehrlich pathway
Description: The Ehrlich pathway describes a specific catabolic process for amino acids, leading to alcohol production, which is a direct component of amino acid metabolism.

While primarily a cell division process, septum digestion involves cellular remodeling and coordination, which can be broadly linked to the cellular surveillance and dynamics pathways that mitochondria participate in, such as those related to cellular structure and fate.
Telomere maintenance is a crucial process for genome stability, broadly aligning with the high-level concept of 'central dogma' in a cellular context, even though it pertains to nuclear DNA.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Coenzyme Q metabolism
Description: Ubiquinone (Coenzyme Q) is a vital electron carrier in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, and its biosynthesis is a specific metabolic pathway within mitochondria.

While primarily an ER process, the maintenance of the ER tubular network is closely linked to mitochondrial function and morphology, particularly through organelle contact sites (MAMs) that facilitate inter-organelle communication and lipid exchange.

Autophagy is a cellular degradation process, and its regulation (including negative regulation) is a key aspect of cellular surveillance, directly listed under mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Organelle contact sites
Description: This process describes the assembly of contact sites between cellular organelles (nucleus and vacuole), which, by extension, relates to the broader cellular concept of organelle communication and dynamics, a category that includes mitochondrial organelle contact sites.

GO_description: positive regulation of proteasomal ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process
Description: While the proteasome is primarily cytosolic, the regulation of ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism is crucial for overall cellular protein homeostasis, including the degradation of mitochondrial proteins or proteins destined for mitochondria, and is influenced by mitochondrial health.

GO_description: tail-anchored membrane protein insertion into ER membrane
Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting
Description: Although this GO term specifies insertion into the ER membrane, the fundamental process of tail-anchored membrane protein insertion is a type of protein import and sorting, a general cellular mechanism that also applies to mitochondrial membrane proteins.
Deaminase activity is a general enzymatic function involved in various metabolic processes, such as amino acid or nucleotide catabolism, which are fundamental to mitochondrial metabolism.

GO_description: negative regulation of telomere maintenance via telomerase
Description: This process describes the regulation of telomere maintenance, a crucial aspect of genome stability, broadly aligning with the high-level concept of 'central dogma' in a cellular context, even though it pertains to nuclear DNA.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Coenzyme A metabolism
Description: Coenzyme A catabolism is a direct aspect of Coenzyme A metabolism, which is a cofactor essential for various mitochondrial metabolic pathways.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Coenzyme A metabolism
Description: Acetyl-CoA hydrolase activity directly impacts the levels and utilization of acetyl-CoA, a derivative of coenzyme A, thus falling under coenzyme A metabolism.
This GO term directly describes the process of mitochondrial inner membrane fusion, which is a key aspect of mitochondrial dynamics.

Pathway: Metabolism > Lipid metabolism > Fatty acid oxidation
Description: Fatty acid beta-oxidation is the primary mitochondrial pathway for breaking down fatty acids, directly corresponding to the fatty acid oxidation category under lipid metabolism.
Citrate synthase activity is the initial and rate-limiting step of the TCA cycle, a central pathway in carbohydrate metabolism.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > NAD biosynthesis and metabolism
Description: NADPH regeneration is essential for maintaining cellular redox balance and is directly related to the metabolism of NAD/NADP cofactors.

Pathway: Metabolism > Nucleotide metabolism > Nucleotide synthesis and processing
Description: Deoxyribonucleotide biosynthesis provides the essential building blocks for mtDNA replication, a core process within mitochondrial nucleotide metabolism.

GO_description: regulation of endoplasmic reticulum unfolded protein response
Description: While primarily an ER process, mitochondrial function and stress significantly influence the regulation of the ER unfolded protein response, placing it broadly under mitochondrial signaling.

GO_description: poly(U)-specific exoribonuclease activity, producing 3' uridine cyclic phosphate ends
Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mtRNA stability and decay
Description: This exoribonuclease activity is involved in the degradation and processing of RNA, which is a key aspect of mtRNA stability and decay within the mitochondrial central dogma.
Mitochondria are central to maintaining intracellular monoatomic ion homeostasis, which is a critical signaling function.

Phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate phosphatase activity is involved in the modification and regulation of phosphatidylinositol, a type of phospholipid, thus fitting into mitochondrial phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA repair
Description: The DNA damage response in mitochondria specifically addresses damage to mtDNA, which is maintained and repaired as part of mtDNA maintenance.
Phosphoglycerate kinase activity is a fundamental part of carbohydrate metabolism, specifically glycolysis, which is closely linked to mitochondrial energy production.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: Glutathione peroxidase activity is a key component of the mitochondrial antioxidant defense system, directly involved in the metabolism of ROS and glutathione for detoxification.
Hydrolase activity is a very general enzymatic function involved in the breakdown of various molecules, making 'Metabolism' the most appropriate broad category.

Pathway: Metabolism > Lipid metabolism > Type II fatty acid synthesis
Description: Acyl carrier activity is central to fatty acid synthesis, specifically the mitochondrial Type II fatty acid synthesis pathway.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Carnitine shuttle
Description: Carnitine O-palmitoyltransferase activity is a crucial enzymatic step in the carnitine shuttle, which facilitates the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria for metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: Cysteinyl-tRNA aminoacylation is the process of charging a tRNA with cysteine, a function performed by mt-tRNA synthetases for mitochondrial protein translation.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: tRNA aminoacylation is the fundamental process of charging tRNAs with amino acids, which is carried out by mt-tRNA synthetases for mitochondrial protein translation.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: Isoleucyl-tRNA aminoacylation is the process of charging a tRNA with isoleucine, a function performed by mt-tRNA synthetases for mitochondrial protein translation.

Protein O-linked glycosylation is a post-translational modification. While not a canonical mitochondrial process, 'Protein homeostasis' is the most appropriate general category for protein modifications and quality control within the mitochondrial pathway hierarchy.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Fe-S cluster biosynthesis
Description: This GO term directly refers to the assembly of iron-sulfur clusters, which are essential cofactors for many mitochondrial proteins, placing it squarely in the 'Fe-S cluster biosynthesis' pathway.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: Mitochondria have their own translation machinery, including specific tRNA synthetases to charge mitochondrial tRNAs. Tryptophan-tRNA ligase is an example of an mt-tRNA synthetase.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Proteases
Description: Ubiquitination often marks proteins for degradation by proteasomes. Mitochondrial protein quality control involves ubiquitination and subsequent degradation by mitochondrial proteases, making 'Proteases' the most fitting sub-category under protein homeostasis.

Spindle pole body organization is a key process in cell division. While not directly mitochondrial, mitochondria are dynamic organelles whose distribution and behavior are regulated during cell division, making 'Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance' the broadest relevant category for organelle organization and behavior.
Mitochondria are increasingly recognized as central hubs in cellular signaling, interacting with and being influenced by various signaling pathways. This term directly relates to signaling processes.

Phosphopyruvate hydratase (enolase) is a key enzyme in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. Gluconeogenesis is a specific carbohydrate metabolic pathway listed in the hierarchy with mitochondrial connections.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: This activity, typically performed by glutathione reductase, is crucial for maintaining cellular redox balance and is a core component of the mitochondrial antioxidant defense system, directly fitting 'ROS and glutathione metabolism'.

Pathway: Metabolism > Nucleotide metabolism > Nucleotide synthesis and processing
Description: Mitochondria require nucleotides for mtDNA replication and mtRNA synthesis. Deoxycytidyl transferase activity is involved in nucleotide synthesis and processing, which is essential for mitochondrial nucleic acid metabolism.

GO_description: termination of RNA polymerase II transcription, poly(A)-coupled
Description: While RNA polymerase II is typically nuclear, this GO term describes a fundamental process of RNA transcription termination. As mitochondria have their own RNA metabolism, 'mtRNA metabolism' is the broadest category related to RNA processing within the mitochondrial central dogma, despite the specific enzyme being nuclear.
Fructose 6-phosphate is a central intermediate in carbohydrate metabolism, including glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, which are pathways with significant mitochondrial involvement.

The ATP:ADP antiporter (adenine nucleotide translocase, ANT) is a crucial mitochondrial transporter belonging to the SLC25A family, responsible for exchanging ATP and ADP across the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Ethanol metabolism, particularly by aldehyde dehydrogenase, can occur in mitochondria. 'Metabolism' is the appropriate general category as there is no more specific sub-pathway for ethanol metabolism in the hierarchy.

Pathway: Metabolism > Carbohydrate metabolism > Glycerol phosphate shuttle
Description: This GO term directly relates to the metabolism of glycerol-3-phosphate, a key component of the glycerol phosphate shuttle, which transfers reducing equivalents into the mitochondria.

Mitochondria play a critical role in cellular signaling, particularly in calcium homeostasis and ATP production, both of which are essential for the regulation of exocytosis. Therefore, 'Signaling' is the most appropriate category.

This GO term describes a cellular component. As mitochondria are intracellular membrane-bounded organelles, the 'Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance' category, which deals with the organelle's physical nature, organization, and behavior, is the most fitting pathway for this component-level description.

GO_description: positive regulation of mitotic actomyosin contractile ring assembly
Description: This process is central to cytokinesis during cell division. Similar to spindle pole body organization, it relates to cellular organization and division, which impacts mitochondrial distribution and dynamics, making 'Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance' the most relevant category.

The Cvt (cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting) pathway is a specific type of autophagy. Autophagy, including mitophagy, is a key process for mitochondrial quality control and is listed under 'Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance'.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA repair
Description: Mitochondria contain their own DNA (mtDNA) and possess repair mechanisms to maintain its integrity. DNA exonuclease activity is a crucial component of mtDNA repair pathways.

Many proteins involved in mitochondrial lipid metabolism, membrane structure, and dynamics exhibit lipid binding activity. 'Lipid metabolism' is the most direct and appropriate broad category for processes involving lipids.

Pathway: Signaling > Calcium homeostasis > EF hand proteins
Description: Calcium ion binding is fundamental to mitochondrial calcium signaling, and EF hand proteins are a major class of calcium-binding proteins involved in this process.
Glycogen metabolism is a core carbohydrate metabolic process, providing glucose units that can eventually be metabolized by mitochondria.
This GO term directly describes the activity of ABC transporters, which are a specific category of small molecule transporters found in the mitochondrial hierarchy.
Protein kinase binding is a fundamental regulatory interaction, often initiating or modulating signaling cascades, which aligns with the general 'Signaling' category.
Many mitochondrial dicarboxylic acid transporters belong to the SLC25A family, which are crucial for shuttling metabolites like malate and succinate across the mitochondrial membrane.
This GO term directly describes the metabolic processes involving pyruvate, which is a specific sub-pathway under carbohydrate metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mtRNA stability and decay
Description: Binding to AU-rich regions in mRNA 3'-UTRs is a well-known mechanism for regulating mRNA stability and degradation, which is a key aspect of mitochondrial RNA metabolism.
RNA splicing is a fundamental process of RNA maturation and processing, which falls under the broader category of mitochondrial RNA metabolism.
Aggrephagy is a specialized form of autophagy that targets protein aggregates for degradation, aligning with the broader cellular process of autophagy for quality control.
Phosphatidic acid is a crucial intermediate in phospholipid biosynthesis, including mitochondrial phospholipids like cardiolipin, making its binding activity relevant to phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Metabolism > Nucleotide metabolism > Nucleotide synthesis and processing
Description: This GO term directly describes the synthesis of purine nucleotides, which is a specific process within the broader nucleotide metabolism pathway.

GO_description: positive regulation of fatty acid biosynthetic process
Pathway: Metabolism > Lipid metabolism > Type II fatty acid synthesis
Description: This GO term describes the regulation of fatty acid synthesis, and Type II fatty acid synthesis is the specific pathway for fatty acid synthesis occurring within mitochondria.

Pathway: Metabolism > Nucleotide metabolism > Nucleotide synthesis and processing
Description: 'De novo' IMP biosynthesis is a fundamental process for generating purine nucleotides, directly falling under the broader category of nucleotide synthesis and processing.
This GO term broadly covers the metabolic processes involving alpha-amino acids, which is the overarching category for amino acid metabolism.

GO_description: regulation of mitochondrial DNA metabolic process
Description: This GO term describes the regulation of all processes related to mitochondrial DNA, which is encompassed by the broader category of mtDNA maintenance.
This GO term describes the activity of transporting pyruvate across a membrane, which is a fundamental function of small molecule transport into the mitochondria.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Chaperones
Description: The mitochondrial prohibitin complex is known to function as a chaperone, playing a critical role in protein quality control and homeostasis within the mitochondria.
Responding to arsenic, a toxic xenobiotic substance, involves detoxification mechanisms, which are categorized under xenobiotic metabolism.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: The mitochondrial unfolded protein response is a crucial cellular mechanism for maintaining protein homeostasis within the mitochondria by addressing protein misfolding stress.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: Protein urmylation is a post-translational modification that can influence protein function, stability, and interactions, thereby contributing to overall protein homeostasis within the mitochondria.
NADH dehydrogenase (Complex I) is the first complex in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, responsible for oxidizing NADH and pumping protons.
This describes the core function of ATP synthase (Complex V), which utilizes the proton motive force across the inner mitochondrial membrane to synthesize ATP.

Pathway: Metabolism > Lipid metabolism > Fatty acid oxidation
Description: Acetyl-CoA C-acyltransferase (thiolase) is a key enzyme in the final step of mitochondrial fatty acid beta-oxidation, cleaving off acetyl-CoA units.
RNA binding is a fundamental molecular function for proteins involved in all aspects of mitochondrial RNA metabolism, including transcription, processing, modification, and stability.

Pathway: Metabolism > Lipid metabolism > Cholesterol, bile acid, steroid synthesis
Description: This enzyme activity is directly involved in the synthesis and modification of sterols, which falls under the broader category of cholesterol and steroid synthesis within lipid metabolism.

Pathway: Metabolism > Vitamin metabolism > Folate and 1-C metabolism
Description: This enzyme (methionine synthase) is a key player in the folate and one-carbon metabolism pathway, essential for various methylation reactions.
The FAR/SIN/STRIPAK complex is involved in various cellular signaling pathways that can indirectly influence mitochondrial function and dynamics.

While intra-Golgi transport is not a direct mitochondrial process, cellular trafficking and organelle dynamics are interconnected, and this general transport mechanism could indirectly influence mitochondrial function.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Proteases
Description: Serine-type endopeptidases are a class of proteases, which play a vital role in mitochondrial protein homeostasis, including protein maturation and degradation.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: Hydroxyacylglutathione hydrolase (Glyoxalase II) is part of the glyoxalase system, which detoxifies reactive aldehydes, a process related to cellular detoxification and protection against oxidative stress.

Pathway: Metabolism > Lipid metabolism > Type II fatty acid synthesis
Description: This enzyme activity is a key step in the Type II fatty acid synthesis pathway, which occurs in mitochondria.

Phosphorylation is a ubiquitous post-translational modification that plays a critical role in regulating numerous mitochondrial processes, including metabolism, OXPHOS, and protein import, often as part of signaling pathways.
This GO term directly describes a signaling pathway that communicates between mitochondria and the nucleus, fitting perfectly into the general 'Signaling' category.
Pyruvate dehydrogenase activity is the crucial step converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis to the TCA cycle and thus central to mitochondrial carbohydrate metabolism.
Monosaccharide binding is a molecular function relevant to the transport and metabolism of carbohydrates within mitochondria, such as glucose uptake or intermediates of carbohydrate metabolism.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: Protein maturation encompasses processes like folding, modification, and assembly, which are essential for maintaining the functional integrity of mitochondrial proteins and thus falls under protein homeostasis.

GO_description: matrix side of mitochondrial inner membrane
Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Intramitochondrial membrane interactions
Description: This GO term describes a specific mitochondrial compartment. The 'Intramitochondrial membrane interactions' pathway relates to the structural organization and interactions of mitochondrial membranes, of which the matrix side of the inner membrane is a crucial part.
Vesicle fusion is a fundamental membrane trafficking process. In the context of mitochondria, it is directly relevant to mitochondrial fusion, a key aspect of mitochondrial dynamics.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: The detection of misfolded proteins is a critical aspect of protein quality control, ensuring the proper functioning of the mitochondrial proteome, and thus falls under protein homeostasis.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: Alanine-tRNA ligase (alanyl-tRNA synthetase) is an enzyme responsible for attaching alanine to its cognate tRNA, a crucial step in mitochondrial protein translation.
Phosphatidylinositol phosphates (PIPs) are phospholipids, and mitochondria are involved in phospholipid synthesis and remodeling, including precursors for cardiolipin.

Pathway: Metabolism > Amino acid metabolism > Glutamate metabolism
Description: Glutamate metabolism is a specific pathway listed under amino acid metabolism, which is a core mitochondrial function.
Sphingolipids are a class of lipids, and mitochondria are central to overall cellular lipid metabolism and homeostasis, even if not the primary site of sphingolipid synthesis.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: Phosphatases are enzymes that regulate protein function through dephosphorylation, a key aspect of maintaining protein homeostasis and functional state within mitochondria and the cell.

Pathway: Metabolism > Amino acid metabolism > Urea cycle
Description: The urea cycle is a well-known metabolic pathway that occurs partly within the mitochondrial matrix.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > Mitochondrial ribosome assembly
Description: Mitochondria have their own ribosomes (mitoribosomes), and their assembly is a crucial part of mitochondrial translation.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: Aminoacylation of tRNA is performed by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases, and mitochondria possess their own set of mt-tRNA synthetases essential for mitochondrial protein synthesis.

The exocyst complex is involved in vesicle trafficking and exocytosis. While not directly mitochondrial, its regulation is a general cellular signaling process that can indirectly impact mitochondrial function or cellular context.

Septin rings are cytoskeletal structures involved in cell division. Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance includes processes like fission and fusion, and the segregation of mitochondria during cell division is influenced by cellular structural components.

Actin cytoskeleton is crucial for cellular dynamics, including organelle positioning and movement. Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance encompasses how mitochondria interact with the cytoskeleton for trafficking and localization.
Manganese is an essential metal cofactor for several mitochondrial enzymes, such as manganese superoxide dismutase (Mn-SOD).

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting
Description: The mitochondrial intermembrane space is a key compartment for protein import and sorting, serving as a destination for many imported mitochondrial proteins.
In yeast and fungi, the vacuole is the primary degradative organelle, analogous to lysosomes, and plays a crucial role in the final stages of autophagy and mitophagy.
Oxygen is the terminal electron acceptor in the electron transport chain, specifically bound and reduced by Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) during oxidative phosphorylation.

ATP synthase (Complex V) is the primary enzyme responsible for ATP synthesis in mitochondria, and its function is critically dependent on ATP binding (in reverse, for hydrolysis) or ADP/Pi binding (for synthesis).

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Organelle contact sites
Description: The Sec62/Sec63 complex is part of the ER translocon. Mitochondria and the ER form extensive contact sites (MAMs), and ER function, mediated by complexes like Sec62/Sec63, can influence mitochondrial dynamics and function.

GO_description: fungal-type cell wall beta-glucan biosynthetic process
Description: Beta-glucan is a carbohydrate, and its biosynthesis is a metabolic process. While not directly mitochondrial, carbohydrate metabolism is a major category within mitochondrial functions.
Mitochondria rely on the transport of various small molecules, including carbohydrates or their derivatives (e.g., pyruvate), across their membranes for metabolic processes.

GO_description: Golgi to plasma membrane protein transport
Description: This describes a general cellular process of protein sorting and transport. While specific to the Golgi and plasma membrane, the overarching category of 'Protein import, sorting and homeostasis' broadly covers protein localization and management within the cell.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mtRNA stability and decay
Description: Mitochondria have their own ribosomal RNA (mt-rRNA), and mechanisms for its quality control and degradation are essential for mtRNA stability and decay.

GO_description: regulation of retrograde protein transport, ER to cytosol
Description: This GO term describes a general cellular protein quality control mechanism (ERAD pathway). While not exclusively mitochondrial, protein homeostasis is a broad category that encompasses cellular mechanisms for protein quality and degradation, which are vital for overall cellular health and indirectly impact mitochondrial function.

Pathway: Metabolism > Nucleotide metabolism > Nucleotide synthesis and processing
Description: This enzyme activity is a key step in the de novo purine biosynthesis pathway, which falls under nucleotide synthesis.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: The anaphase-promoting complex (APC/C) is a ubiquitin ligase involved in targeted protein degradation during the cell cycle. This represents a general cellular protein degradation and quality control mechanism, fitting broadly into protein homeostasis.

This GO term describes a cellular compartment (the nucleus), not a pathway. However, nuclear-encoded proteins are essential for all aspects of mitochondrial central dogma (mtDNA maintenance, mtRNA metabolism, translation), making this the most general, albeit indirect, connection within the hierarchy.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA replication
Description: The replication fork is the site of DNA replication. Mitochondria contain their own DNA (mtDNA) and undergo replication, making this a direct fit for mtDNA replication.

Lipoyltransferases are enzymes that attach lipoic acid to target proteins. Lipoate insertion is a specific process within mitochondrial lipid metabolism, as lipoic acid is a crucial cofactor for several mitochondrial enzyme complexes.
Atg8-family proteins (e.g., LC3) are essential for autophagosome formation, a key step in autophagy, including the selective degradation of mitochondria (mitophagy).
L-malate dehydrogenase is a crucial enzyme in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, a central metabolic pathway in the mitochondrial matrix.

L-aspartate is transported across the mitochondrial inner membrane by specific carriers, often members of the SLC25A family (e.g., AGC1/2), as part of the malate-aspartate shuttle and other metabolic processes.
Microtubules serve as tracks for the intracellular movement and positioning of mitochondria, a process known as mitochondrial trafficking.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > Mitochondrial ribosome
Description: Mitochondria possess their own ribosomes, which are responsible for synthesizing proteins encoded by mtDNA, making this a direct fit for mitochondrial translation.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-rRNA modifications
Description: This enzyme activity modifies ribosomal RNA (rRNA). Mitochondrial rRNA (mt-rRNA) undergoes various modifications, including methylation, which are crucial for the assembly and function of mitochondrial ribosomes.
Plus-end-directed microtubule motors (e.g., kinesins) are responsible for moving mitochondria along microtubules, which is a key aspect of mitochondrial trafficking.

This is a very general term for transport across membranes. Mitochondria are highly active in various forms of transmembrane transport, including the import of small molecules, which is covered by the 'Small molecule transport' category.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) is involved in regulating S-nitrosothiol levels, which are linked to nitric oxide signaling and redox homeostasis, a critical aspect of ROS and glutathione metabolism for cellular detoxification.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: This describes a modification of transfer RNA (tRNA). Mitochondrial tRNAs (mt-tRNAs) undergo various post-transcriptional modifications, including pseudouridylation, which are essential for their proper function in mitochondrial translation.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Organelle contact sites
Description: Phosphatidylinositol (PI) and its derivatives are signaling lipids crucial for membrane trafficking and establishing organelle contact sites, such as ER-mitochondria contact sites, which regulate mitochondrial dynamics and function.

This GO term describes a cellular compartment membrane. While not a mitochondrial membrane itself, the concept of inter-organelle membrane interactions and contact sites is highly relevant to mitochondrial biology, particularly with the ER, making 'Organelle contact sites' the most appropriate general category.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: This enzyme activity modifies transfer RNA (tRNA) by methylation. Mitochondrial tRNAs (mt-tRNAs) undergo various modifications, including methylation, which are essential for their proper function in mitochondrial translation.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Organelle contact sites
Description: Phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate (PI4P) is a signaling lipid involved in membrane trafficking and is enriched at organelle contact sites, including ER-mitochondria contact sites, where it plays a role in lipid transfer and signaling, impacting mitochondrial dynamics.
Microtubules are essential for the intracellular transport and positioning of mitochondria, making microtubule binding relevant to mitochondrial trafficking.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: Mitochondria are primary sites of reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and possess elaborate systems for sensing and responding to oxidative stress, including ROS detoxification.

While this GO term specifically refers to ER chaperones, the broader concept of protein chaperones is critical for protein homeostasis, a key function within mitochondria. This is the most conceptually related category.

Pathway: Metabolism > Vitamin metabolism > Folate and 1-C metabolism
Description: Folic acid (folate) metabolism is directly linked to one-carbon metabolism, a vital pathway occurring in mitochondria, as explicitly listed in the hierarchy.

Pathway: Metabolism > Vitamin metabolism > Folate and 1-C metabolism
Description: Folic acid biosynthesis is a specific aspect of folate metabolism, which is a key mitochondrial vitamin and one-carbon metabolic pathway.

Telomerase inhibitor activity is primarily a nuclear process. However, given the requirement to assign to a mitochondrial pathway, and the broad impact of mitochondrial health on cellular signaling and aging, 'Signaling' is chosen as the most general, albeit indirect, category.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting
Description: Mitochondria import the vast majority of their proteins from the cytosol, making protein transporter activity a fundamental aspect of mitochondrial protein import and sorting.

Pathway: Metabolism > Vitamin metabolism > Folate and 1-C metabolism
Description: Tetrahydrofolylpolyglutamate biosynthesis is a crucial step in folate metabolism, which is directly linked to mitochondrial one-carbon metabolism.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: Regulation of protein processing, including cleavage and maturation, is integral to maintaining protein homeostasis within mitochondria.

GO_description: methylglyoxal catabolic process to D-lactate via S-lactoyl-glutathione
Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: Methylglyoxal is a toxic metabolite whose catabolism often involves glutathione-dependent pathways, aligning with the broader mitochondrial detoxification processes, including those related to ROS and glutathione.
Aldehyde dehydrogenase activity, particularly NAD+-dependent forms, is crucial in mitochondria for detoxifying various endogenous and exogenous aldehydes, which falls under xenobiotic metabolism.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Tetrahydrobiopterin synthesis
Description: Tetrahydrobiopterin is an essential cofactor, and its biosynthesis is explicitly listed as a mitochondrial metabolic pathway in the hierarchy.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: Cytochrome-c peroxidase activity is involved in the detoxification of reactive oxygen species (specifically hydrogen peroxide) using cytochrome c, thus fitting within the ROS and glutathione metabolism pathway.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Chaperones
Description: Protein disulfide isomerase activity is essential for the correct folding and maturation of proteins, particularly those with disulfide bonds, and thus contributes to mitochondrial protein homeostasis, similar to chaperone functions.

While fructose import across the plasma membrane is not a direct mitochondrial process, it represents a form of small molecule transport into the cell, which can then be metabolized, potentially by mitochondria. This is the most general transport category available.

Mating projection base is a cellular structural component, primarily observed in yeast. While not directly a mitochondrial pathway, mitochondrial dynamics and morphology are integral to overall cellular structure and function, making this the most broadly related category.
Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is a central intermediate in carbohydrate metabolism, particularly in gluconeogenesis, a pathway explicitly listed in the mitochondrial hierarchy.

Nuclear-transcribed mRNA catabolism is primarily a cytoplasmic process. However, given the requirement to assign to a mitochondrial pathway, and the fact that most mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear genes, 'Mitochondrial central dogma' is chosen as the most general category related to genetic information flow, albeit indirectly.

Box C/D snoRNPs are involved in rRNA modification and processing in the nucleolus. While specific to nuclear rRNA, the general concept of rRNA processing and assembly into ribosomes is mirrored in mitochondrial ribosome assembly.

Short-chain carboxylesterase activity is involved in the hydrolysis of various esters, including xenobiotics and endogenous compounds, contributing to detoxification processes that can occur in mitochondria.

This is a cytosolic process, but cytosolic ribosomes synthesize the vast majority of mitochondrial proteins. Therefore, it is indirectly essential for mitochondrial protein supply and falls under the broad umbrella of cellular protein handling, which includes mitochondrial protein import and homeostasis.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: Adenylylation is a post-translational modification that regulates protein activity and stability, contributing to the overall maintenance and quality control of proteins, which is a core aspect of protein homeostasis.

Fermentation is an anaerobic metabolic pathway for carbohydrate breakdown, occurring in the cytosol. While not a mitochondrial process itself, it is a fundamental part of cellular carbohydrate metabolism and interacts with mitochondrial energy pathways.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Proteases
Description: This is the primary pathway for degrading misfolded or unwanted proteins in the cytosol and nucleus. Although the proteasome is not mitochondrial, it is the major cellular proteolytic system, and protein degradation is a key component of protein homeostasis, which includes mitochondrial protein quality control.

Phospholipase A1 enzymes hydrolyze phospholipids, which are essential components of mitochondrial membranes and are involved in various signaling pathways. This activity directly relates to phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting
Description: The transport of misfolded proteins, whether for degradation or re-folding, is a specialized form of protein movement and sorting within the cell, often involving inter-compartmental transfer, which aligns with the broader category of protein import and sorting.

Pathway: Metabolism > Carbohydrate metabolism > Glycerol phosphate shuttle
Description: This enzyme is a key component of the glycerol phosphate shuttle, which transfers reducing equivalents from the cytosol to the mitochondrial electron transport chain, making it a direct part of mitochondrial carbohydrate metabolism.

Methyltransferase activity is a broad enzymatic function involved in numerous metabolic pathways, including those for nucleotides, amino acids, lipids, and cofactors. Given its general nature, 'Metabolism' is the most appropriate overarching category.
This term directly describes the initiation step of protein synthesis within the mitochondria, which is a core process of the mitochondrial central dogma.

Phosphatidylinositol and its derivatives are phospholipids involved in signaling and membrane dynamics. Their dephosphorylation is a key step in their metabolism and regulation, fitting directly into phospholipid metabolism.

Clathrin-dependent endocytosis is a major cellular process for internalizing extracellular material and membrane components. Its regulation involves complex signaling pathways, making 'Signaling' the most appropriate general category, even though it's not a direct mitochondrial process.

This describes the process of directing proteins to a specific organelle (the vacuole). While the vacuole is not a mitochondrion, this falls under the general cellular mechanisms for protein targeting and sorting to various compartments.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mtRNA stability and decay
Description: A mitochondrial degradosome is a complex responsible for the degradation of mitochondrial RNA, directly contributing to the stability and decay of mtRNA.
Allyl-alcohol dehydrogenase is involved in the metabolism of xenobiotics (foreign compounds), a key function of cellular detoxification pathways, often involving mitochondria.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: This term refers to the cellular mechanisms, such as the unfolded protein response, that are activated to cope with protein misfolding and maintain protein quality, which is central to protein homeostasis.

A cellular response to stress, such as salt stress, involves complex signal transduction pathways that coordinate various cellular adjustments. 'Signaling' is the most appropriate general category for such a response.

GO_description: adenylate cyclase-activating G protein-coupled receptor signaling pathway
Description: This describes a specific and well-defined signaling cascade that leads to the activation of adenylate cyclase and subsequent cAMP-PKA signaling, which is explicitly listed in the hierarchy.

Signal recognition particle (SRP) binding is a crucial step in targeting nascent proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum for import. While not mitochondrial, it is a fundamental mechanism of cellular protein import and sorting to organelles.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Organelle contact sites
Description: The cortical ER forms extensive contact sites with mitochondria (Mitochondria-Associated Membranes, MAMs), which are critical for lipid exchange, calcium signaling, and mitochondrial dynamics. Thus, it directly relates to organelle contact sites.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis
Description: Ubiquitin chain polymerization is a key step in ubiquitination, a post-translational modification that regulates protein degradation (e.g., via the proteasome) and other cellular processes, thereby playing a crucial role in maintaining protein homeostasis.
Mitochondrion inheritance involves the proper distribution and movement of mitochondria to daughter cells, a process directly related to mitochondrial trafficking and dynamics.
G-proteins are crucial components of many cellular signaling pathways, including those that regulate mitochondrial function, often acting upstream of cAMP-PKA signaling.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > Translation > mt-tRNA synthetases
Description: Aminoacylation of tRNA by tRNA synthetases is an essential step in protein translation, specifically performed by mitochondrial tRNA synthetases for mitochondrial protein synthesis.
Triose-phosphate isomerase is a key enzyme in glycolysis, a central carbohydrate metabolic pathway that provides substrates for mitochondrial energy production.
This GO term directly describes the inhibition of cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA), a central component of the cAMP-PKA signaling pathway.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Proteases
Description: Serine-type endopeptidases are a class of proteases, and their inhibition directly impacts protein degradation and turnover, which are critical aspects of protein homeostasis.
This enzyme activity is directly involved in the synthesis and modification of phospholipids, a core process within phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA replication
Description: DNA polymerase gamma is the primary enzyme responsible for the replication of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).
This GO term describes the movement of small molecules (hexoses) across a membrane, which is the fundamental function of small molecule transport.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA repair
Description: Binding to damaged DNA is a crucial initial step in the process of repairing mitochondrial DNA.
This GO term describes the movement of a small molecule (spermidine) across a membrane, which is the fundamental function of small molecule transport.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: Thiol oxidase activity is often involved in maintaining cellular redox balance, forming disulfide bonds, and managing reactive oxygen species, which are central to ROS and glutathione metabolism.

GO_description: oxidoreductase activity, acting on the CH-OH group of donors, NAD or NADP as acceptor
Description: This is a broad enzymatic activity fundamental to numerous metabolic pathways, including carbohydrate, lipid, and amino acid metabolism, which are all encompassed under the general 'Metabolism' category.

While 'nucleus' is a cellular compartment, it is the primary site for encoding and transcribing the vast majority of mitochondrial proteins, which are subsequently imported into the mitochondrion. This pathway represents the downstream process of nuclear gene expression for mitochondrial function.

Although phospholipid scrambling occurs at the plasma membrane, mitochondria are central to phospholipid synthesis and metabolism, and there are inter-organelle lipid exchanges that can influence plasma membrane composition and dynamics.
This enzymatic activity directly involves the modification or breakdown of a phospholipid (phosphatidylethanolamide), linking it to phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: This complex is involved in modifying tRNA, specifically in the transamidation pathway for glutaminyl-tRNA synthesis, which falls under mt-tRNA modifications.
Acetate is often metabolized to acetyl-CoA, a key input for the TCA cycle, making it a fundamental part of central carbon metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-rRNA modifications
Description: This enzyme directly modifies mitochondrial ribosomal RNA through methylation, a specific type of mt-rRNA modification.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Chaperones
Description: Cellular heat acclimation often involves the upregulation and activity of chaperones to maintain protein folding and prevent aggregation under heat stress, which is a core aspect of protein homeostasis.
Catalyzes a step in the synthesis of phosphatidylcholine from phosphatidylethanolamine, which is a core phospholipid metabolic process.
Catalyzes the hydrolysis of sphingomyelin, a sphingolipid, which is a component of general lipid metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: Describes a specific post-transcriptional modification of mitochondrial tRNA, essential for proper mitochondrial translation.
Refers to the movement of ceramide, a lipid, across membranes, which falls under general small molecule transport.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Intramitochondrial membrane interactions
Description: Refers to a specific sub-compartment of the inner mitochondrial membrane, whose integrity and interactions are crucial for mitochondrial dynamics and function.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein homeostasis > Proteases
Description: Describes the enzymatic activity of a protease, which is central to protein degradation and processing, maintaining protein homeostasis within the mitochondrion.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting > Preprotein cleavage
Description: Refers to the enzymatic removal of signal peptides from precursor proteins after their import into the mitochondrion, a key step in protein maturation.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA repair
Description: Catalyzes the removal of uracil from DNA, a crucial initial step in base excision repair, which is a major pathway for mtDNA repair.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Cristae formation
Description: Describes the ability to induce curvature in biological membranes, a fundamental process involved in mitochondrial morphology changes, including cristae formation.
A protein complex with phosphatase activity, involved in the dephosphorylation of proteins, a critical regulatory mechanism in various cellular signaling pathways.
Directly refers to the metabolic pathways involved in the synthesis and breakdown of ketone bodies.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Coenzyme A metabolism
Description: A protein complex responsible for the synthesis of Coenzyme A, a vital cofactor in numerous mitochondrial metabolic reactions.
Refers to the activity of proteins that facilitate the movement of nucleotides across biological membranes, a process essential for mitochondrial nucleotide metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Intramitochondrial membrane interactions
Description: Describes the non-covalent association with phospholipids, which are fundamental components of mitochondrial membranes and crucial for their structure and interactions.
Describes the activity of an ABC transporter specifically involved in moving glutathione S-conjugates, fitting the general category of ABC transporters.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA replication
Description: Refers to the initial steps of DNA synthesis, which in mitochondria specifically applies to the replication of mitochondrial DNA.

Pathway: Protein import, sorting and homeostasis > Protein import and sorting > Import motor
Description: Describes the enzymatic activity of an ATPase that powers the translocation of proteins into the mitochondrion, a core function of the mitochondrial import motor.
Refers to the activity of a symporter protein that transports carbohydrates along with protons, directly contributing to carbohydrate metabolism.
Describes the non-covalent interaction with peptides, which can be involved in various mitochondrial processes such as protein import (e.g., presequence recognition) or protein degradation.

Pathway: Metabolism > Vitamin metabolism > Vitamin B2 metabolism
Description: Catalyzes a step in the biosynthesis of riboflavin (Vitamin B2), directly falling under vitamin metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtDNA maintenance > mtDNA repair
Description: Double-strand break repair is a critical process for maintaining the integrity of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), directly fitting into mtDNA repair mechanisms.

Aggresome assembly is a cellular response to overwhelming misfolded proteins. While primarily cytosolic, mitochondrial dysfunction can contribute to misfolded protein load, and cellular protein homeostasis mechanisms (including those that handle misfolded mitochondrial proteins) are broadly related.

Pathway: Metabolism > Lipid metabolism > Type II fatty acid synthesis
Description: Holo-acyl-carrier-protein synthase is essential for activating acyl carrier protein (ACP), a key component of the mitochondrial Type II fatty acid synthesis (FASII) pathway.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: This enzyme activity is involved in repairing oxidized methionine residues in proteins, a crucial part of antioxidant defense against reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are abundantly produced in mitochondria.

This is a cellular component term. While not a pathway, 'side of membrane' is a fundamental concept for understanding membrane structure and interactions, which are central to intramitochondrial membrane dynamics and organization.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: Pseudouridine is a common RNA modification. Mitochondria perform modifications on their own tRNAs and rRNAs, which are essential for their structure and function in mitochondrial translation.

N-acylphosphatidylethanolamines are a class of phospholipids, and their metabolism is part of the broader phospholipid metabolism, which is relevant to mitochondrial membrane composition and signaling.

While 'plasma membrane' is specified, lactate is converted to pyruvate, which is then transported into mitochondria for metabolism. This term represents an upstream process directly feeding into mitochondrial pyruvate metabolism.
This enzyme activity is directly involved in the acylation of lysophospholipids to form phospholipids, a key aspect of phospholipid synthesis and remodeling within mitochondria.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: This enzyme is involved in the detoxification of formaldehyde via the glutathione-dependent pathway, contributing to the overall detoxification and ROS management systems in mitochondria.

This is a nuclear/cytoskeletal component. While not a mitochondrial pathway, mitochondria provide energy for cell division processes involving kinetochores, and mitochondrial dynamics are coordinated with the cell cycle. This is the most general category for mitochondrial physical aspects and behavior.

SCF ubiquitin ligases are E3 ligases involved in the ubiquitin-proteasome system. While primarily cytosolic, this system targets and degrades proteins, including mitochondrial proteins or those that fail mitochondrial import, thus contributing to overall cellular and mitochondrial protein homeostasis.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > NAD biosynthesis and metabolism
Description: Nicotinamide nucleotides (NAD+/NADH) are central cofactors in numerous mitochondrial metabolic pathways, including OXPHOS and the TCA cycle, making their metabolism directly relevant.

GO_description: regulation of pyruvate decarboxylation to acetyl-CoA
Description: Pyruvate decarboxylation to acetyl-CoA, catalyzed by the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, is a key step in mitochondrial carbohydrate metabolism, linking glycolysis to the TCA cycle.

Phosphatidylcholine flippase activity is involved in the transport and distribution of phospholipids across membranes, which is crucial for maintaining mitochondrial membrane composition and function, falling under phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Metabolism > Detoxification > ROS and glutathione metabolism
Description: This enzyme activity detoxifies reactive 2-alkenals, which are products of lipid peroxidation often induced by mitochondrial ROS, thus contributing to mitochondrial detoxification and oxidative stress defense.

Pathway: Metabolism > Metals and cofactors > Coenzyme A metabolism
Description: Coenzyme A (CoA) is a vital cofactor for numerous mitochondrial metabolic pathways, including fatty acid oxidation and the TCA cycle, making its metabolism directly relevant.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: This enzyme catalyzes the formation of pseudouridine, a key modification in mitochondrial tRNAs and rRNAs, essential for their function in mitochondrial translation.

Microtubules are essential for mitochondrial trafficking and positioning within the cell. The regulation of microtubule nucleation is a prerequisite for microtubule formation, thus indirectly supporting mitochondrial trafficking.

Actin filaments are known to play a role in mitochondrial fission, particularly in recruiting fission machinery. The organization of actin structures is therefore indirectly linked to mitochondrial fission.

Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > mt-tRNA modifications
Description: This GO term directly describes an enzymatic activity involved in modifying mitochondrial tRNA, which is a specific process within mitochondrial RNA metabolism.

This general term for promoting the formation or growth of an organelle aligns with the broader processes of mitochondrial biogenesis and structural maintenance, which are encompassed by mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance.

This GO term describes the movement of long-chain fatty acids, which are critical substrates for mitochondrial beta-oxidation, across membranes, fitting into the general category of small molecule transport.

This GO term describes the movement of aminophospholipids, which are essential components of mitochondrial membranes and involved in lipid metabolism, across membranes, fitting into the general category of small molecule transport.
AMP kinase is a key energy sensor that regulates numerous metabolic pathways, including those in mitochondria, acting as a central component of cellular signaling.
This GO term describes a metabolic process involving 3-keto-sphinganine, which is an intermediate in sphingolipid synthesis, a sub-category of general lipid metabolism.
The CDP-choline pathway is the main pathway for phosphatidylcholine synthesis, which is a fundamental process within phospholipid metabolism.

Pathway: Mitochondrial dynamics and surveillance > Cristae formation
Description: Membrane tubulation is a key process in shaping mitochondrial membranes, most notably in the formation of cristae, which are tubular invaginations of the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Amphisome-lysosome fusion is a critical step in the autophagic pathway, where cellular components are delivered to lysosomes for degradation, a process closely related to mitochondrial quality control (mitophagy).
A phagophore is the precursor membrane structure that initiates the engulfment of cellular material during autophagy, a process essential for cellular recycling and mitochondrial quality control.

GO_description: endonucleolytic cleavage to generate mature 5'-end of SSU-rRNA from (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA)
Pathway: Mitochondrial central dogma > mtRNA metabolism > Polycistronic mtRNA processing
